articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: US Domestic News: From Fauci's Denial to Trump's Fundraising Surge
articles.description: This summary highlights major current US domestic news, including Dr. Fauci denying suppressing the COVID lab leak theory, the trial of tech founder Mike Lynch, Hunter Biden's gun charges, Trump's campaign fundraising, and more. Key topics also cover social media regulations and a high-profile lawsuit involving Jeffrey Epstein's alleged sex trafficking network.
articles.content:
Following is a summary of current US domestic news briefs.
Fauci denies suppressing COVID lab leak theory before US House panel

articles.title: Biden to get power to seal US border in tough immigration move
articles.description: A surge in border crossings from Mexico has become a potent political issue for the president and rival Donald Trump ahead of the November 5 election.

articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: Vince Fong Takes Congressional Seat in Special Election
articles.description: Republican Vince Fong of California has been sworn into Congress after winning a special election to fill the remainder of Kevin McCarthy's term. Endorsed by Trump and McCarthy, Fong's victory bolsters the Republican majority in the House. He aims to address key issues including border security and the rising cost of living.
articles.content:
In a significant political development, Republican Vince Fong of California was sworn into Congress on Monday following a special election victory. The election was held to complete the term of deposed former US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
Fong, wh... [963 chars]

articles.description: President Biden on Monday rallied against President Trump after his conviction to donors at a fundraiser, arguing that “something snapped” after he lost the 2020 election.

articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: Trump's Unprecedented Fundraising Surge Post-Conviction
articles.description: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and the Republican National Committee reported an impressive $141 million in fundraising for May, nearly doubling the previous month's total. This surge followed Trump's conviction for falsifying business records. The campaign claims the fundraising reflects public outrage over what they call a politically motivated prosecution.
